title: What are some good Chinese history books that are written in Chinese? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A, Audrey. I agree with Tom Xu’s answer here, 上下五千年 (Five Thousand Years of Chinese Nation) could be an excellent series for Chinese language learners. In fact, I owned a box of comic 上下五千年 with Pinyin on, as my bedtime stories. After I finished the almighty-but-smartass-monkey & good-for-nothing-but-being-loved-by-everybody pig story, aka 西游记 (Journey to the West), I decided to read some real thing instead of fictions, with my limited Chinese character skills. My dad bought me comic version 上下五千年 and 三国演义 (The Romance of the Three Kingdoms) as my birthday gift. Amusingly, those stories which were supposed to be ‘history’ or at least ‘based on history’ seemed more fictional than fictions. Later on, I got to know 三国演义 is more likely a fictional novel, which is why it’s called 演义, or in English, romance. Still, even the history taught in my text book always used a tone that the authors know exactly what people 2000 years ago thought. Yeah, just like what Meng Feifei pointed out in her answer, ‘subjective’. Good or bad, Chinese historians seem love such a subjective way, and Chinese readers seem love it too. My another recommendation of Chinese history book is 中国通史 (History of China) by 吕思勉. It’s much more academic and tougher to read. So being a lazy butt, I never really finished it. Yet I absolutely recommend it not because I am an evil person who like others suffering (or I am?), but because this book is not a chronicle like many history books are. The author wrote it in a comprehensive way, by topics- Cultural topics: Marriage. Clans. Property. Taxation… Political topics… like this.   (Images are from 《中国通史》 吕思勉 书评 简介 电子书下载 Kindle电子书) So it’s easy to pick a topic you like anytime, from anywhere, without being forced to read chapter by chapter. And… it’s written in a super subjective tone too, which portrays a history world viewed from a Chinese individual’s eyes, reflecting lots of Chinese philosophies and values. I assume it could be very different hence interesting from Chinese learners’ eyes who are from very different cultures and backgrounds. Oh, as a cheap skate, I must mention this: If you are a kindle user, this book is available in “kindle unlimited” service. So enjoy some history combined facts and opinions (which we could hardly tell which is which, like most things in this world), from a different angle, in a different language, for free.

Upon most occasions, I normally try not to read any voluminous history books, if it is possible. As China has more than 4000 years of history, it is almost impossible for our ordinary folks to go through all of the authorized history books in a short time. 二十四史 (Twenty-Four Histories)? Oh No, give me a break…I'd end up wasting my whole life... Apart from that, I find most history books dull. I simply can't focus my attention to read stories that are lacking details, that's why I always in favor of literature, because they are FUNNY and full of details, for example I wouldn't be bothered to read 三国志 if I hadn’t read 三国演义. Of course I understand that there are a lot of artistic licenses in literature works, but history books are not entirely credible. OK vent over. I sense most mainland Chinese will recommend the following two books: Ch'ien_Mu’s 国史大纲 A General History of ChinaLyu Simian’s 中國通史 General History of China (I guess Taiwanese readers would recommend Fu Lecheng’s version)I won't pretend to have finished the above two , I’d go crazy if someone demands me to finish them… There were only two brief points that stuck in my head: Ch’ien Mu's book followed a very traditional Chinese sinocentric writing style, after reading a few paragraphs, I have already taken pride of being Chinese. I have huge respect for him especially after I learnt the background of the creation. By contrast, Lyu Simian’s General History of China is a quite balanced one, he often has unique perspectives on a lot of Chinese historical figures and never falls into the category of lousy cliches. Of course, I have to admit that I am in fact quite bias in favor of Hunanese historians, therefore I would also recommend the following two books: 王夫之 (Wang Fuzhi)《讀通鑑論 , I particularly love Wang Fuzhi’s language, 锋芒毕露, 高山峨峨, which I can only find in Mencius (book), forget to mention that I am a big fan of Mencius. 陈寅恪 (Chen Yique/Tschen Yin Koh） 《柳如是别传》, it is a supplementary biography of Liu Rushi, a legend lady and a courtesan in the late Ming dynasty. (Yes 如是 was chosen from the famous poem 我见青山多妩媚,料青山见我应如是). This book took Chen eleven years to complete after he lost his sight and was being tortured by Red guards during the cultural revolution. Thanks for the A2A, Kevin.
